something that is going to be funny to a

to tell a narrative that we think is
important and what was important to us
is telling an LGBT narrative is that
people could relate to and that people

enjoyable you know it's very easy comedy
to punch down and I think that that's a

like I know what hurts and it is so much

jokes that come from a place of
positivity
it was absolutely meant to be an LGBT
title just the the idea of a game for
people who might not have a game that is
representative of them I think it
originally branched from creating
something that was kind of revolving
around bad jokes and bad culture but the
first note we got into it we realized it
would kind of be disingenuous for it
should not be a sense about these issues
and as like a clear woman it was really
important to me that we were able to
tell a queer story that lightheartedness
on disability and respectful of the
states in the game do you think a game
like this could have become as popular
as it has done 10 years ago oh I don't
think it could have been as successful
ten years ago partially because of we
become a lot more open to LGBT stories
but also because of the way that we
share things on the Internet there are a
lot of organically shareable elements to
it
so instead of us doing an advertisement
or a trailer there was a lot of people
drawing and writing fanfiction making
means throughout the game goes to screen
caps how do you respond to criticism
about the game perhaps drawing on
stereotypes it seems like the response
the game has been overwhelmingly
positive especially from within the LGBT
community which is really exciting and
of course there's no such thing as
perfect representation that doesn't mean
they should try it can't be everything
for everybody but hopefully that will
inspire somebody else to do a better job
than we have the biggest response from
fans that we've gotten about the game is
that this is an important thing to them
they they feel glad that they were able
to play a game that was wholesome and
kind and and positive
